pullRequest.title: feature(subsystems): extract DiscordRPCSubSystem
pullRequest.bodyText:
Contains
New gradle-modules folder - subsystems
Extracted DiscordRPC subsystem - used by PCFacade only.
DiscordRPC was used in PlayerConfig directly - implemented config property observer. (like in rendering configs for runtime graphics settings changing)
How to test
Required:

Discord desktop

TestCases:

run game.
enable DIscord in settings
start game
check status in Discord
rename your player name
check changes in discord (seems)

Outstanding before merging

 improve subproject.settings.gradle and convert it in kotlin
 make configs composite( migrate to FlexableConfigs) - for removing discord config property from engine
 (can be my dirty workspace) fix error with logs

nodes.bodyText:
I'd like to take the chance to put some docstring here. Will take a closer look at this file to answer the following questions:

what does it do? what kind of data does it hold?
how does subscription work? how should that be used?
any general notes?

@DarkWeird feel free to share some thoughts on this, I'll take care of making the Englishz fancy 🤓 🙃
Gradle confuses me 🧐  Do you use backticks, single quotes, or double quotes here in the plugin section?

Let's make sure that there is a README in subsystems/DiscordRPC to explain how this works and how it is supposed to be used. Maybe we should even have a README in the subsystems folder itself to explain the separation. Would be a good place to the diagrams you shared in Discord, too 😉
Let's update all the license headers in the extracted subsystem to use the shorter two-line license.

@@ -0,0 +1,13 @@
+// This magically allows subdirs in this subproject to themselves become sub-subprojects in a proper tree structure
+new File(rootDir, 'subsystems').eachDir { possibleSubprojectDir ->
+    if (!possibleSubprojectDir.name.startsWith(".")) {
+        def subprojectName = 'subsystems:' + possibleSubprojectDir.name
+        println "Processing facade $subprojectName, including it as a sub-project"
+        include subprojectName
+        def subprojectPath = ':' + subprojectName
+        def subproject = project(subprojectPath)
+        subproject.projectDir = possibleSubprojectDir
+    } else {
+        println "Ignoring entry $possibleSubprojectDir as it starts with ."

commit.message: docs(subsystems): add Readme for DiscordRPC subsystem
feature(subsystems): add separate configuration for subsystems and add it to classpath

Does "subsystem" need to be quoted here?
I prefer using logger.info instead of println for this sort of thing. It will make these messages show up when running gradlew --info but also allow it to be hidden during quiet builds.

nodes.bodyText:
It would be nice to complete #4157 before introducing new complications to the facade build.
I think I would have stuck with the built-in implementation Configuration for the subsystems here instead of making a custom Configuration for them.
I can start to imagine why it might be nice to separate them. For example, if we had a lot of Subsystems, and a bunch of other direct dependencies, and we had some troubleshooting use case where we needed to see the Subsystem dependencies independently and there was a nice diagnostic report for that —
but I don't expect that to be the case, and I'm concerned it's not worth the added complexity to the build file and the loss of edit-time type-checking on the custom Configuration name. Are there other benefits to it I have overlooked?

What does this need from publish.gradle?
do we expect subsystems to be published as independent artifacts to the jar repository?

commit.message: chore(subsystems): Use logger.info for subsystems. use common.gradle instead publish.gradle
feature(subsystems): re-integrate afk subsystem handling in discord submodule

Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/develop' into feature/extract-DiscordSubmodule

# Conflicts:
#	facades/PC/build.gradle.kts
